title: Clinical Cases
text: These are a list of all the conferences and talks that I have given during clinical training, ranging from residency, fellowship, and in practice. Most of these are focused on clinical cases, which have all been de-identified.

title: Clinical Cases
text:
Cardiology Fellowship

January 24, 2023 Brief cardiac catheterization case conference on complex/staged PCI.
December 07-08, 2022 A lecture series on AVNRT, including an introduction, an overview of typical AVNRT, These include surface ECG, EGM, and pacing maneuvers.
May 24, 2022 Brief cardiac catheterization case conference discussion of a triple-vessel disease patient with UGIB that was surgically turned down for bypass, pending surgery for infection.
February 16, 2022 Pulmonary Embolism Response Team introduction and overview at the Jesse Brown VA system for the internal medicine residency.
February 08, 2022 Pulmonary Embolism Response Team introduction and overview at the Jesse Brown VA system for both medicine residents and cardiology fellows.
December 07, 2021 Short cardiac catheterization case conference on a NSTEMI that may benefit from CABG, a ICM that may benefit from protected PCI, and a complex, heavily calcific peripheral case.
November 30, 2021 Illinois Medical District Cath Conference presentation on Wellen’s Syndrome in a LAD STEMI patient.
November 23, 2021 Short cardiac catheterization case conference on a late-presenting STEMI at the time of a massive CVA, and a standard peripheral intervention to the left iliac arteries.
November 16, 2021 Short cardiac catheterization case conference with a two-vessel CAD pre-transplant that was revascularized, and two STEMI cases.
November 16, 2021 An introduction to antiplatelet agents in atherosclerotic disease.
November 09, 2021 Short cardiac catheterization case conference with an anterior STEMI and no-reflow to LAD.
October 18, 2021 A mortality and morbidity conference on rheumatic heart disease and mitral stenosis, deferring percutaneous balloon mitral valvuloplasty for surgical mechanical mitral valve replacement.
October 12, 2021 Short cardiac catheterization case conference, with RCA Shockwave, interesting coronary anatomy, and a case of false-positive stress testing with anginal symptoms.
October 05, 2021 Short cardiac catheterization case conference, with LM bifurcation disease using DK crush, a LAD orbital atherectomy case, and a high right radial with severe spasm.
September 28, 2021 Short cardiac catheterization case conference, with a focus on severe disease
September 28, 2021 An introduction to femoral access for new cardiology fellows.
September 09, 2021 Short cardiac catheterization case conference, with a focus on CABG revascularization
June 01, 2021 Cardiac catheterization lab conference, with a few STEMIs from call.
March 16, 2021 Cardiac catheterization lab conference, with a focus of three PCI cases.
February 01, 2021 A journal club on GALACTIC-HF
December 23, 2020 A brief overview of cardiac tamponade for the POCUS curriculum for internal medicine residents.
December 14, 2020 An interesting case of restrictive cardiomyopathy, including workup and consideration of alternative etiologies.

title: Clinical Cases
text:
Internal Medicine Residency

February 18, 2019 As a medical resident, we complete a senior grand rounds, a summative talk of an area of our choosing. I researched psychological triggers for sudden cardiac death, and gave a “chalk talk” style presentation. There was an associated handout and notes with references. The concept of psychological triggers as affecting the ventricular substrate is fascinating, particularly as we learn more of the role of the autonomic nervous system in cardiovascular disease.
September 26, 2018 Another bite-sized teaching mode talk on transfusions in sickle cell. Gave this talk again on October 4, 2018 at the Southern Hospital Medicine conference as an example of alternative teaching methods.
March 21, 2018 With literature from early-terminated trials during 2018, I gave a journal club lecture on the updated guidelines on thrombectomy for ischemic strokes. My notes for it serve as a reference and series of citations, with a handout to improve viewer interaction. The largest issue I find was in the interpretation of their Table 1 showing non-adjusted odds ratios for an ordinal scale, listed next to a P-value.
March 15, 2018 As a resident, there is a shift into becoming a teacher to both medical students and near-peers while being a learner as well. A significant amount of residents actually develop critical failures in the learning process. Here is an approach I presented, with supporting literature and an outline to be shared.
February 28, 2018 I gave a bite-sized teaching mode talk on treating rashes. The purpose of this style of talk is to explain and actually teach a topic in less than 8 minutes. Giving the talk itself emphasized learning how to teach.

title: AVNRT: Part 1
text:
Epidemiology
Approximately 50% of SVT cases in adults are from an AVNRT mechanism (Issa, Miller, and Zipes 2018)

title: Typical AVNRT
text:
Objectives

Understand the relevant anatomy and physiology that allow for AVNRT
Know how to diagnose typical AVNRT from …

Clinical history
Surface ECG
Intracardiac electrograms

Understand the underlying mechanisms behind treatment strategies

title: Typical AVNRT
text:
Definition

SVT implies involvement of ≥ 1 structure above bifurcation of the His bundle (HB).
AVNRT is usually a narrow-complex tachycardia that uses the AV node, and functional/anatomical pathways (slow/fast)


Remains unclear if there are anatomical correlates with the regions of slow versus fast conduction.

title: Typical AVNRT
text:
Incidence
Approximately 50% of SVT cases in adults are from an AVNRT mechanism (Issa, Miller, and Zipes 2018)

title: Typical AVNRT
text:

Abbreviation | Definition |
HB | His bundle |
SAN | sinoatrial node |

CS | coronary sinus |
ST | sinus tachycardia |
SVT | supraventricular tachycardia |
AVNRT | AVN reentrant tachycardia |
AVRT | AV reentrant tachycardia |
AT | atrial tachycardia |

AVNRT is typically a narrow-complex tachycardia




SVT implies involvement of ≥ 1 structure above the bifurcation of the His bundle (HB).

title: Typical AVNRT
section: Does the history and physical matter?
text:
Does the history and physical matter?

Dizziness and hypotension occur more commonly in short RP tachycardias
Polyuria/diuresis during tachycardia or at termination due to increased ANP secretion [Abe1997b]
Neck pounding manifests with continuous pulsing cannon A waves, as the RA contracts against a closed tricuspid valve, described as the frog sign (5)

Does not occur in orthodromic AVRT, as longer VA interval separates the chamber contractions
7-fold increase in AVNRT over other SVT with this symptom

title: Typical AVNRT
section: A differential for a regular SVT?
text:
A differential for a regular SVT?


Narrow QRS

AVNRT
AT
Orthodromic AVRT due to an accessory pathway
AFL with fixed AV conduction
SANRT
High septal VT
ST


Wide QRS

AVNRT or AT with aberrancy
AVNRT with a bystander accessory pathway
Antidromic AVRT due to an accessory pathway
SVT with wider QRS due to electrolyte/AAD therapies

title: Typical AVNRT
text:
Does the physical matter?

Dizziness and hypotension occur more commonly in short RP tachycardias
Neck pounding manifests with continuous pulsing cannon A waves, as the RA contracts against a closed tricuspid valve, described as the frog sign (5)

Does not occur in orthodromic AVRT, as longer VA interval separates the chamber contractions
7-fold increase in AVNRT over other SVT with this symptom

title: Typical AVNRT
text:
Does the history matter?

Sudden onset and termination (often positional) more often re-entrant
Abortive measures such as drinking iced water
Dizziness and hypotension occur more commonly in short RP tachycardias
Polyuria/diuresis during tachycardia or at termination due to increased ANP secretion (5)

title: Typical AVNRT
text:
Does the exam matter?

Neck pounding manifests with continuous pulsing cannon A waves, as the RA contracts against a closed tricuspid valve, described as the frog sign (6)

Does not occur in orthodromic AVRT, as longer VA interval separates the chamber contractions
7-fold increase in AVNRT over other SVT with this symptom

title: Typical AVNRT
text:
Adenosine
90% success rate:

6 mg bolus
12 mg bolus
18 mg bolus

Adenosine works on Y2a receptor by increasing XXX


Can repeat doses after 1 minute, as end-organ effects are complete within 30 seconds.

title: Typical AVNRT

title: AVNRT: Part 2
text:
Differential

Atypical AVNRT
Non-reentrant junctional tachycardia (junctional ectopic tachycardia)
Non-paroyxsmal junctional tachycardia (d/t digitalis-induced DADs)
Dual AV nodal tachycardia (repetitive retrograde concealment or “linking” phenomenon)

title: AVNRT: Part 2
text:
Objectives

Review relevant anatomy and physiology of relevant components of conduction system

title: Typical AVNRT
text:
Physiology

slow pathway identification
fast pathway identification
describe why the conduction system is different
explain refractory perioids
describe anterograde/retrograde conduction


Mode of intiation of tachycardia
atrial activation sequence during tachycardia
influence of budnel bracnch block on conduction / cycle length during tachycardai
requirement fo atria/ventricle to initiate and sustain tachycardia
atrial/ventricula r stim during tachycardia
drugs/physiological maneuvers on the tachycardia

SVT implies involvement of ≥ 1 structure above bifurcation of the His bundle (HB).
AVNRT is usually a narrow-complex tachycardia that uses the AV node, and functional/anatomical pathways (slow/fast)

section: A differential for a regular SVT?
text:
A differential for a regular SVT?


Narrow QRS

AVNRT
AT
Orthodromic AVRT due to an accessory pathway
AFL with fixed AV conduction
SANRT
High septal VT

Wide QRS

AVNRT or AT with aberrancy

title: Introduction to AVNRT
text:
Does the history matter?

Sudden onset and termination (often positional) more often re-entrant
Abortive measures such as drinking iced water
Dizziness and hypotension occur more commonly in short RP tachycardias
Polyuria/diuresis during tachycardia or at termination due to increased ANP secretion (5)


What next?


Physical exam?



24-48 hour Holter?
2-4 weeks of cardiac event monitoring?
Exercise testing?
Echocardiogram?
EP testing?



Video


https://youtu.be/csVn_kvdeBM

title: Introduction to AVNRT
text:
Does the exam matter?

Neck pounding manifests with continuous pulsing cannon A waves, as the RA contracts against a closed tricuspid valve, described as the frog sign (6)

Does not occur in orthodromic AVRT, as longer VA interval separates the chamber contractions
7-fold increase in AVNRT over other SVT with this symptom

title: Introduction to AVNRT
text:
Vagal Maneuvers


Valsalva maneuver

Also called Flack’s test, where intrapleural pressure is raised to 40 mm Hg (expiration against closed airway)
Bradycardia effect seen within first 10-15 seconds











Carotid sinus massage

Holding constant pressure (not a “massage”) for 5-10 seconds
Increases pressure in carotid body, firing baroreceptors
SNS afferent response leads to PNS efferents via vagus (right = SA, left = AV)
Responses…

cardioinhibitory with ≥ 3s pause
vasodepressor is drop of ≥ 50 mm Hg in pressure
mixed





Adenosine



an endogenous purine nuceloside, binding to cardiac adenosine A1 receptors
dose-related prolongation of AV conduction at AH interval


90% success rate:

6 mg bolus
12 mg bolus
18 mg bolus

Repeat dosing after 1 minute (30 seconds for complete effect). Better efficacy with “single syringe strategy” (8)

title: Part 3: Atypical AVNRT
text:
Differential

Atypical AVNRT
Non-reentrant junctional tachycardia (junctional ectopic tachycardia)
Non-paroyxsmal junctional tachycardia (d/t digitalis-induced DADs)
Dual AV nodal tachycardia (repetitive retrograde concealment or “linking” phenomenon)

title: Part 3: Atypical AVNRT
text:
Objectives

Review relevant anatomy and physiology of relevant components of conduction system

title: Part 3: Atypical AVNRT
text:
Evaluation

Mode of initiation of tachycardia
Atrial activation sequence during tachycardia
Influence of bundle branch block on conduction and cycle length during tachycardia
Requirement of atria/ventricle for initiation and maintenance of tachcyardia
Effect of atrial/ventricular stiulation during tachycardia
Effect of drugs or physiological maneuvers on tachycardia

title: Introduction to AVNRT
text:
Requirements
To initiate and maintain a re-entrant rhythm:

≥ 2 functionally/anatomically distinct pathways that join proximally and distally to form a closed circuit of conduction
unidirectional block in one of those potential pathways
slow conduction down the unblocked pathway, allowing the previous pathway to recover

Sina qua non of reentrant arrhythmia is the ability to reproducibly intiate the tachycardia by timed extrastimuli

title: Introduction to AVNRT
text:
tach_start <- read_lspro(file.path(loc, "tmf_data/lsp-tach-initiation.txt"))

ggm(data = tach_start,
        channels = c("I", "CS", "RV", "HIS d", "HIS m")) |>
    add_intervals(channel = "I")




Tachycardia initiation






ggm(data = tach_start,
        channels = c("I", "CS", "RV", "HIS d", "HIS m"),
        time_frame = c(2.6, 2.9))




A beat from the tachycardia






ggm(data = tach_start,
        channels = c("I", "CS", "RV", "HIS d", "HIS m"),
        time_frame = c(0.6, 1.0))




A beat from the sinus






ggm(data = tach_start,
        channels = c("I", "CS", "RV", "HIS d", "HIS m"),
        time_frame = c(1.5, 3.0))




APD leads to tachycardia






avnrt <-
    ra_grey +
    geom_sf(data = pathways, fill = "white", color = NA_character_) +
    geom_sf(
        data = filter(pathways,
                                    structure == "slow" & component == "middle"),
        fill = orange[3]
    ) +
    geom_sf(
        data = filter(
            pathways,
            (structure == "slow" & component == "distal") |
                (structure == "bridge" & component == "distal")
            ),
        fill = orange[3]
    ) +
    geom_sf(
        data = filter(pathways, structure == "lower_common"), 
        fill = orange[3]
    ) +
    geom_sf(
        data = filter(pathways,
                                    structure == "fast" & component == "distal"),
        fill = red[2]
    ) +
    geom_sf(
        data = filter(pathways,
                                    structure == "fast" & component == "middle"),
        fill = red[2]
    ) +
    geom_sf(
        data = filter(
            pathways,
            (structure == "fast" & component == "proximal") |
                (structure == "bridge" & component == "proximal")
            ),
        fill = red[2]
    ) +
    geom_sf(
        data = filter(
            pathways,
            (structure == "upper_common" & component == "distal") |
                (structure == "upper_common" & component == "upper_fast")
            ),
        fill = red[2]
    ) +
    geom_sf(
        data = filter(pathways,
                                    structure == "upper_common" & component == "upper_slow"),
        fill = orange[2]
    ) +
    geom_sf(
        data = filter(
            pathways, 
            (structure == "atrial_extension") |
                (structure == "slow" & component == "proximal")
        ),
        fill = c(red[2], orange[3], rep(red[2], 4))
    ) 

avnrt +
    transition_layers(
        keep_layers = c(Inf, Inf, rep(1, 9)),
        layer_length = 1,
        from_blank = FALSE
    ) +
    enter_fade() +
    exit_fade(alpha = 0)






decremental_800 <-
    read_lspro(file.path(loc, "tmf_data/lsp-cs-pacing-800.txt")) 

ggm(decremental_800, channels = c("I", "CS", "HIS")) |>
    add_intervals(channel = "CS 9-10")




Decremental pacing at 800 ms






decremental_400 <-
    read_lspro(file.path(loc, "tmf_data/lsp-cs-pace-decremental-400ms-jump.txt"))

ggm(decremental_400, channels = c("I", "CS", "HIS")) |>
    add_intervals(channel = "CS 9-10")




Decremental pacing at 400 ms

title: Typical AVNRT
text:
Objectives

Understand the concepts of dual node physiology
Know the requirements for typical AVNRT
Evaluate the response of standard EP maneuvers in typical AVNRT

title: Typical AVNRT
text:
Abbr.
Abbreviation




DAD
delayed after-depolarization


EAD
early after-depolarization


APD
atrial premature depolarization


VPD
ventricular premature depolarization


RAAS
retrograde atrial activation sequence

title: Part 2: Typical AVNRT
text:
Criteria

Initiation and termination by APD/VPD during AV nodal Wenckebach cycles
Dual AV nodal physiology (differential refractory curves during APD)
Initiation dependent on critical AH interval during slow pathway conduction
Retrograde atrial activation with variable VA activation in Triangle of Koch
Initiated, terminated, or reset without atrial activation



Slow-fast AVNRT has atrial activation close to QRS complex, such that AH/HA > 1

title: Typical AVNRT
text:
Differential…

Typical AVNRT
Orthodromic AVRT
Atypical AVNRT
Atrial tachycardia always a possibility
Non-reentrant junctional tachycardia (junctional ectopic tachycardia)
Non-paroyxsmal junctional tachycardia (d/t digitalis-induced DADs)
Dual AV nodal tachycardia (repetitive retrograde concealment or “linking” phenomenon)

title: Typical AVNRT
text:
Evaluation

Mode of initiation of tachycardia
Atrial activation sequence during tachycardia
Influence of bundle branch block on conduction and cycle length during tachycardia
Requirement of atria/ventricle for initiation and maintenance of tachcyardia
Effect of atrial/ventricular stimulation during tachycardia
Effect of drugs or physiological maneuvers on tachycardia

title: Part 2: Typical AVNRT
section: SVT features prior to diagnostic pacing maneuvers
text:
SVT features prior to diagnostic pacing maneuvers
For typical AVNRT, there are some findings to help eliminate options.

VA Relationship: any pattern, but most commonly V=A and V<A
VA Interval: VA ≤ 70
Atrial Activation Sequence: concentric
Spontaneous Termination: end either in A or V response
VA Increase with BBB: no

title: Introduction to AVNRT
text:
1. Kwaku KF, Josephson ME. Typical AVNRT - An update on mechanisms and therapy. 2002;6:414–421. Available at: https://link.springer.com/article/10.1023/A:1021140509804.


2. Issa ZF, Miller JM, Zipes DP. Clinical arrhythmology and electrophysiology: A companion to braunwald’s heart disease. Elsevier; 2018:1–752. Available at: https://linkinghub.elsevier.com/retrieve/pii/C20140032935.


3. Goyal R, Zivin A, Souza J, et al. Comparison of the ages of tachycardia onset in patients with atrioventricular nodal reentrant tachycardia and accessory pathway-mediated tachycardia. American Heart Journal 1996;132:765–767. Available at: https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/8831363/.


4. Porter MJ, Morton JB, Denman R, et al. Influence of age and gender on the mechanism of supraventricular tachycardia. Heart Rhythm 2004;1:393–396.


5. Abe H, Nagatomo T, Kobayashi H, Miura Y, Masaru Araki AK, Nakashima Y. Neurohumoral and hemodynamic mechanisms of diuresis during atrioventricular nodal reentrant tachycardia. PACE - Pacing and Clinical Electrophysiology 1997;20:2783–2788. Available at: https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/9392809/.


6. Sakhuja R, Smith LM, Tseng ZH, et al. Test characteristics of neck fullness and witnessed neck pulsations in the diagnosis of typical AV nodal reentrant tachycardia. Clinical Cardiology 2009;32:E13. Available at: /pmc/articles/mid/NIHMS319317/ /pmc/articles/mid/NIHMS319317/?report=abstract https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC3200305/.


7. Brugada J, Katritsis DG, Arbelo E, et al. 2019 ESC Guidelines for themanagement of patients with supraventricular tachycardia. European Heart Journal 2020;41:655–720. Available at: www.escardio.org/guidelines.


8. Kotruchin P, Chaiyakhan I on, Kamonsri P, et al. Comparison between the double-syringe and the single-syringe techniques of adenosine administration for terminating supraventricular tachycardia: A pilot, randomized controlled trial. Clinical Cardiology 2022;45:583–589.

text:
Criteria for typical AVNRT

Initiation and termination by APD/VPD during AV nodal Wenckebach cycles
Dual AV nodal physiology (differential refractory curves during APD)
Initiation dependent on critical AH interval during slow pathway conduction
Retrograde atrial activation with variable VA activation in Triangle of Koch
Initiated, terminated, or reset without atrial activation

title: Typical AVNRT
section: Differential for regular / short RP tachycardia
text:
Differential for regular / short RP tachycardia

Typical AVNRT
Orthodromic AVRT
Atypical AVNRT
Atrial tachycardia always a possibility
Non-reentrant junctional tachycardia (junctional ectopic tachycardia)
Non-paroyxsmal junctional tachycardia (d/t digitalis-induced DADs)
Dual AV nodal tachycardia (repetitive retrograde concealment or “linking” phenomenon)

title: Typical AVNRT
text:
Case setup


Access: RCFV x 3
Catheters:

CS: decapolar catheter
His: quadrapolar catheter
RV: quadrapolar catheter
Ablation: STSF 4 mm

Closure: collagen-plug x 3

Study plan:

Baseline EP study
RA and RV pacing maneuvers (including decremental pacing)
His-refractory PVC
Induction of tachycardia
Entrainment
3D anatomical mapping (CART) with His cloud
Ablation
Post-ablation testing

title: Typical AVNRT
text:
Tachycardia initiation

Tachycardia start:

APD that blocks the fast pathway?
VPD that blocks retrograde?

Activation sequence changes:

Atrial activation is concentric, eccentric, high-to-low?
Are the ventricles and atria activated simultaneously?

title: Typical AVNRT
section: Tachycardia features prior to diagnostic pacing maneuvers
text:
Tachycardia features prior to diagnostic pacing maneuvers
For typical AVNRT, there are some findings to help eliminate options.

VA Relationship: any pattern, but most commonly V=A and V<A
VA Interval: VA ≤ 70

Spontaneous Termination: end either in A or V response

text:

title: Introduction to AVNRT
text:
ra_colors <-
    ra_grey +
    geom_sf(data = chambers, fill = red[5], alpha = 0.1) +
    geom_sf(data = septum, fill = red[5], alpha = 0.1) +
    geom_sf(data = vessels, fill = blue[5], alpha = 0.1) +
    geom_sf(data = projections, fill = red[2], alpha = 0.1) +
    geom_sf(data = valves, fill = grey[9], alpha = 0.1) +
    geom_sf(data = conduction, fill = orange[1], alpha = 0.3) 

ra_colors






ra_colors + 
    geom_sf(data = pathways, fill = "white", color = NA, alpha = 0.8) +
    geom_sf_label(data = filter(pathways, type == "pathway"), aes(label = label), nudge_y = 1)

Warning: Removed 12 rows containing missing values (`geom_label()`).







nsr <-
    ra_grey +
    geom_sf(data = pathways, fill = "white", color = NA_character_) +
    geom_sf(data = filter(pathways, structure == "atrial_extension"),
                    fill = orange[3]) +
    geom_sf(data = filter(pathways, structure == "upper_common"),
                    fill = orange[3]) +
    geom_sf(
        data = filter(
            pathways,
            (structure == "fast" & component == "proximal") |
                (structure == "bridge" & component == "proximal")
            ),
        fill = orange[3]
    ) +
    geom_sf(
        data = filter(
            pathways,
            (structure == "fast" & component == "middle") |
                (structure == "slow" & component == "proximal")
            ),
        fill = orange[3]
    ) +
    geom_sf(
        data = filter(
            pathways,
            (structure == "fast" & component == "distal") |
                (structure == "bridge" & component == "distal")
            ),
        fill = orange[3]
    ) +
    geom_sf(
        data = filter(pathways, structure == "lower_common"),
        fill = orange[3]
    ) + 
    geom_sf(
        data = filter(
            pathways,
            (structure == "slow" & component == "distal") |
                (structure == "slow" & component == "middle")
            ),
        fill = c(red[2], orange[3])
    ) 

nsr +
    transition_layers(
        keep_layers = c(Inf, Inf, rep(2, 7)),
        layer_length = 1,
        from_blank = FALSE
    ) +
    enter_fade() +
    exit_fade(alpha = 0)






nsr_egm <- read_lspro(file.path(loc, "tmf_data/lsp-single-pvc.txt"))

ggm(data = nsr_egm,
        channels = c("I", "CS", "RV", "HIS D", "HIS M", "HIS P"),
        time_frame = c(0.25, 0.7))

title: Hypertrophic Cardiomyopathy
text:
Overview

Thought to be more rare, but now diagnosed more commonly
Incidence of 1:200 to 1:500
Range of phenotypic presentations, 15 mm to ≥ 30 mm LV wall thickness
Clinical presentation along the spectrum of disease:

stable/benign
sudden death
obstructive physiology + heart failure
atrial fibrillation + stroke




Maron et al. JACC 2022

title: Hypertrophic Cardiomyopathy
text:
Clinical evaluation

Discuss: disease and its treatment strategies - genetic conditions necessitate both clinical and psychosocial considerations
HPI: focuses on syncope, prolonged palpitations, chest pain, family history of HCM or sudden death
Establish: LV morphology, stratify sudden death risk, classify if obstructive or not, family screening needs, and follow-up
Evaluate: TTE, ECG (12-lead + ambulatory), CMR, ESE, genetic testing
Follow-up: repeat imaging every 1-2 years (based on clinical setting)

title: Hypertrophic Cardiomyopathy
text:
Diagnostic requirements

LV wall thickness > 15 mm (13 to 14 mm with other risk features)
Unassociated with other cardiometabolic or systemic disease
Sarcomere mutation or other genetic variant



Gersh, BJ, et al. JACC 2011

title: Hypertrophic Cardiomyopathy
text:
Non-mandatory findings

Asymmetrical septal hypertrophy
Systolic anterior motion
Dynamic LVOT obstruction

title: Hypertrophic Cardiomyopathy
Hypertrophic Cardiomyopathy
text:
LVH variant morphology



Figure 3: Variant sub-type correlated with frequency of genetic mutations: sigmoid, reversse, neutral, apical (respectively)




Binder J, et al. Mayo Clin Proc 2006

title: Hypertrophic Cardiomyopathy
text:
Classify LVH morphology







(a) Sigmoid







(b) Reverse







(c) Apical




Figure 4: Location of hypertrophy defines the morphology. No matter where, any region > 30 mm increases risk of SCD, as well as apical pouch.




Ommen et al. 2016, JASE

title: Hypertrophic Cardiomyopathy
text:
SAM



Figure 5: The Venturi effect. LV ejection → obstruction → MR.




Silbinger 2016, JASE

title: Hypertrophic Cardiomyopathy
text:
LVH associated with genetic variants



Figure 2: Variant sub-type correlated with frequency of genetic mutations: sigmoid, reversse, neutral, apical (respectively)




Binder et al. 2006, Mayo Clin Proc

title: Hypertrophic Cardiomyopathy
text:
Gradients
We can compare LV systolic pressure with systemic systolic pressure to estimate obstructive gradients:
\[ LV\ Systolic\ Pressure = 4 \times (MR\ velocity)^{2} + LA\ Pressure\]

Peak LVOT gradient of ≥ 50 mmHg at rest or with provocation or exercise indicates obstruction
Differentiate SAM-mediated LVOT obstruction from mid-ventricular obstruction (MVO; “dagger” shaped)

MR signal is both higher and longer, thus may contaminate LVOT signal

title: Hypertrophic Cardiomyopathy
text:
Pre-operative strategies
Surgical septal myectomy and alcohol septal ablation should have TEE support. Measure:

IVS maximum thickness
anterior leaflet length
apical extent of the septal “bulge”
distance between aortic annulus to mitral-septal continuity

Follow-up TTE in 3-6 months.
